Hey @geodeveloper

Do you have a callback function after the input swal?

If so, I assume you have another swal as the success message, which has its own settings (none of which are inherited by its parent). You would have to redeclare the `showCancelbutton` property.

Hi @fallen-rve,
Yes I have a callback function. I've took the example of input from official sweetalert website and just added the default config on top. Take a look here --> https://jsfiddle.net/a836z9xv/ so you can see the bug.

Thanks for your time.

@geodeveloper gotcha!

That is the expected behavior of `setDefaults`. If you set the `setDefaults` property, it'll apply to all of your SweetAlerts, regardless if it's the shorthand or longhand versions.

From the documentation:
> If you end up using a lot of the same settings when calling SweetAlert, you can use setDefaults at the start of your program to set them once and for all!

Let me know if that clears it up.

Thanks!

@diego-vieira Sorry, the project isn't dead. I just haven't had time to go through pull requests and issues lately.

sweetalert2 was forked before v1.0, so the structure of the project is quite different. This doesn't necessarily mean that it's not a good alternative. If there's a feature in there that you need, you should of course use it.

It kinda bugs med that it's called sweetalert2 though, since that makes it sound like it's a natural progression of this project, even though I'm planning a 2.0 release later this year...

Anyways, free software, do what you like. Just wanted to say sorry for being unresponsive, and that I'm planning on becoming more active soon.

If there are any good candidates to help med maintain the project, please let me know!

Perhaps we could merge your repo with sweetalert2?

Cheers

Your wrapper saved my ass. A few notes. As @QuakePhil mentioned there is an issue if there are multiple alerts in the queue, each with nested responses for confirm/cancel.

In order to deal with this I am closing the parent swal using the ID immediately after the child is created. And in order to pair this Parent (question) - Child(response) scenario, I have made a tiny modification in the wrapper to append all new swals at the beginning of the array/queue and not at the end.

This works with single requests as well. So, consider the following scenario in order to show how the alerts are created:



And here is how the alerts will be displayed to the user:



If you have any questions let me know.

Once again thanks a lot man, the wrapper did an awesome work.

@henryg0mez So if I understand things correctly, the problem is that your form gets submitted even though you haven't entered any input? 

Is this really a problem with SweetAlert? Keep in mind that the only recommended way to handle user inputs through swal is by using `type: input`. Everything else with custom HTML should be considered a "hack".

If your form submits even though it's empty, I can only guess that the problem lies within the  `myForm.valid()`-function.

And when it comes to "I am not sure that anything actually happens on submit. When submit is clicked, a php file is called through AJAX that should send an email", well, you should be able to just log your stuff in the PHP console to check if it went through or not. Can't really help you anymore than this. :)

@t4t5 - yes, the email did submit at first until I modified the code in an attempt to stop the send function if nothing was typed in the fields.

Surely there has to be a way to stop SweetAlert from submitting the form and verify there are actually valid values entered in the fields? I would really like to get form validation working on Swal. Otherwise I am looking at using Wordpress' Contact Form 7 with pop-up as a work around.
@t4t5 It's just a convention. Some of projects (eg. React, Redux) put source code (es6, es7) in `src`, compiled es5 in `lib`, umd and minified files in `dist`.

@samhavens What do you think of being able to add your SweetAlert markup directly in the DOM? Like this:



This would obviously be hidden by default thanks to the SweetAlert CSS. Then you can open it by passing a jQuery element or a DOM node to the swal-function:



The idea is that as long as you follow some conventions when writing your HTML, you get the SweetAlert-functionality for free.

I think it would solve a lot of problems that people have with "over-customizing", like adding a third button, implementing a form... etc.

@t4t5 I think that's a good solution. Currently isn't there only one sweet alert object, and it gets modified every time it pops up? Will having multiples around throw anything off? @t4t5 I think that having the markup and the parameters (via the data-\* attributes) of the modal in the html would be really cool.
Then to open an alert you would have to pass the alert id to the `swal()` function.

Example:





Would add a cancel button then show the modal by adding it the class "current-sweetalert-modal" (to avoid collision with others current classes that the user could have in it's `CSS`.

We could recommend/use a [client-side templating engine](http://garann.github.io/template-chooser/) to structure it all. I personally favour React.js because it supports type validation out of the box when you pass in properties to a component, but of course anything else could work. 

I think the only problem with this solution might be that this would require a significant rewrite. Specifically, `sweetalert-dev.js` has a `switch` statement with an object case that simply updates the default params, rather than let you define your own. Like @t4t5 mentions, there is only one SweetAlert box that keeps getting updated each time. We need a way to 'subclass' objects - to have a base `SweetAlert` object that simply checks the `type` argument supplied, and then calls the template involved. 

One way to do this - and the one I think would be most painless, given how extensive SweetAlert is - would be to have a function called `registerTemplate()`, which registers a template in a store accessible to `swal`. `swal` would then check the `type` argument on being invoked against an internal list -`success`,`input`,`error`,`warning` - and, if not found, default to passing all other arguments to the template and somehow render it. I think `_sweetAlertInitialize$getModal$getOverlay$getInput$setFocusStyle$openModal$resetInput$fixVerticalPosition` might be able to handle the rendering, although I'd have to take a closer look at it, I'm not sure.

Hi @limonte nice work (:  

But how can you trigger a close event in your sweetalert2 plugin? In my case, I'd like to show an overlay with a "well done" or "oops..." message and perform an ajax request in the background. Once the data comes back from the server and is passed to the DOM, the modal should close itself. As I can't predict how long the ajax request will need, I can't use the timer function.

Btw. on line 258 you have an error:  
`params.allowEscapeKey = arguments[0].allowEscapeKey !== undefined ? arguments[0].showConfirmButton : defaultParams.allowEscapeKey;`  

should be:  
`params.allowEscapeKey = arguments[0].allowEscapeKey !== undefined ? arguments[0].allowEscapeKey : defaultParams.allowEscapeKey;`  
(there's `arguments[0].showConfirmButton` in there). If you tell me how I can fetch your fork, I'd fix it my self ;)

@pascalwacker thank you! I fixed that copy-paste typo and added "execute the done function if the modal is closed by the timer" in v.0.1.0 of [sweetalert2](https://github.com/limonte/sweetalert2).

@MBing In a project, I rather not to use more than one modal in perspective of complexity. Also, timer is not a good solution for my goal (Ajax requests). You may not ~~prefer~~ predict the duration of a process. So, an event handler will be inevitable (I think).

@aliemre I am using both in my project. Simple stuff with swal and more complex with modals. Didn't know you had ajax requests. I am using sweetalert with ajax requests when the promise gets returned on a login or logout inside a login service. Works like a charm, the timer only starts when the ajax request is finished and depending on the data I get back it changes the content. Of course I don't know anything about your project or goal. So I assume it might be best to work with the event handler. ;)
Indeed @mwakerman . Actually, my purpose was to use sweet alert as a process notifier. In that case, we cannot assume the time that is needed. So, an event handler should be added.

I think what @leifcr is saying is that he generates a new very brief "1 millisecond" timer which "cancels" the existing timer. Again, adding the cancel alert functionality in my commit was about 3 lines of trivial code and is blocking and doesn't rely on the event queue.

I agree, that a close event would be better, as @mwakerman is right, that it will be on the event queue, since the function does use setTimeout. if its `swal('close')` or swal.cancel is up to @t4t5 to choose.
Anyone found a better solution then @leifcr  or @esecules ?
Anyone found a better solution then @leifcr  or @esecules ?
@MacgyverMartins thanks : Try it: swal.close(); works

By default, it provides the **closeOnConfirm** and **closeOnCancel** parameters that can be set to true or false. Set to true it will close immediately after the click on button. If you want to close just after processing the callback function you can use **swal.close()**, As @MacgyverMartins  quoted above

The simplest possible solution based on the workaround of @JustinWinthers that I could found (without modifying the library), is to hook only into the `swal.close` function and set the `window.onkeydown` to the previous `window.onkeydown` event handler: 



or in my case even simpler:



With this workaround it is now also possible to use the Enter and Escape keys in the dialog. 

The error messages mentioned by @Mr-Anonymous and @EduardJS also no longer occur.

- Pressing enter right after a modal is shown just relaunches the modal (imo, the confirm-button should be selected by default so that you can quickly dismiss it by pressing enter)

There's nothing wrong with a stylistic PR, but it comes across as petty/presumptive when you do it in the same commit as a material change.  Instead of being "hey, I made this pass jshint - what do you think?", it says "clearly a _professional_ would have used the same style as me, so I'm just going to presume that mine is better and change it without talking about it."
